text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full-page miniature occupying the upper half of the folio, bounded by a gilded Gothic micro-architectural frame; a single column of text in Gothic textura beneath; wide blank margins on right and left embellished with gilt vine scrolls

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with red rubrics and blue guide-letters

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf used for background diaper pattern and frame highlights; ultramarine and azurite reserved for architectural backgrounds and important draperies; red and green provide secondary contrast in garments; layered application with white lead highlights on towers and costumes; colors remain vivid with minimal pigment loss

features: Central vertical axis defined by the tall tower
Flanking boats and figures balanced on left and right
Architectural frame creates inward visual focus
Horizontal tiers: water and boats at base, gallery of figures mid-level, battlements and cityscape above

decorative_elements: Gothic micro-architecture border with pinnacles and crockets
Gold diaper pattern on dark blue background
Marginal gilt vine scroll with naturalistic leaves

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill pen work in brown ink for underdrawing; bold outlines in darker pigment
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields with minimal hatching; white lead highlights on folds and masonry
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling; no scientific perspective; overlapping elements suggest depth

content_theme.scene_description: The single historiated scene shows a fortified city labeled "Babilon" at the top of a central pink-and-gray masonry tower flanked by ramparts. On a raised gallery to the left, a procession of haloed figures in long tunics and mantles approach the city gate; the leading figure holds a tall staff or banner. Below, two riverboats glide on dark green waters, each with three fishermen wearing pointed caps and tunics; a central net teems with fish. The tower occupies the vertical center, with two tall cylindrical turrets joined by a crenellated wall and passageway at mid-height. The figures in the gallery are nearly life-size against the tower, indicating importance, while the boats and fishermen are scaled smaller. Costuming details include red mantles lined with blue, green tunics, and white hose; masonry shows fine ashlar patterning. Actions: the haloed group advances in orderly rank toward the gate as the fishermen haul a heavy net, suggesting provisioning or symbolic linkage. The water is rendered with stylized waves.

religious: Haloed figures in long red and blue robes on gallery
secular: Fishermen in two boats wearing pointed caps and short tunics

architectural: Central Gothic-style pink and gray tower with crenellations

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, very smooth flesh side with visible plummet ruling
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation; slight pigment flaking in small areas of red; corners show gentle cockling
notable_physical_characteristics: Underdrawing visible under UV along masonry lines
Punchwork dot pattern in gold diaper background

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This folio likely originates from a mid-14th-century Parisian workshop, reflecting the height of Gothic manuscript illumination and the city’s dominance in luxury book production. The use of burnished gold leaf against a richly diapered ultramarine background, along with the micro-architectural frame, indicates a high-prestige commission, possibly for a cathedral or noble patron with ecclesiastical ties. The depiction of a fortified "Babilon" combines historical narrative with symbolic resonance, hinting at contemporary concerns over urban power and spiritual exile. Stylistically, the rendering of figures with elongated proportions, sharply folded drapery, and schematic wave motifs shows affinity with the so-called "Court School" illuminators in Paris, while the vigorous use of pink lake for masonry suggests technical exchanges with English ateliers. The collaborative nature of the work is evident in varying line quality: a master painter likely executed the faces and architectural elements, while assistants filled in secondary tones. Iconographically, the procession of haloed personages toward the city and the fisheries below may allude both to Old Testament deportations and Christological imagery of the Church’s mission, merging typology and contemporary urban symbolism. Comparatively, the border’s gilded vine scroll and punchwork can be linked to the Psalter of Queen Jeanne of Navarre, indicating a shared decorative repertoire that balances tradition with innovative color handling and narrative integration.
